headline.main: Personal Health; For Many, Air Travel Means a Trip to the Doctor.

docs.lead_paragraph: AIR travel, while a boon to long-distance vacationers and business travelers, has also become an increasing source of pain, discomfort and even illness among passengers and crew members in recent years. While no systematic study has been done on the incidence of flight-related health problems, complaints from passengers have ranged from headache, nausea and backaches to colds, pneumonia and blood clots in the lungs. Airlines have also greatly reduced the influx of fresh air on planes to save money, worsening health problems.

headline.main: Survey Finds Major Gains In Cutting Blood Cholesterol

keywords.value: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Blood cholesterol levels among adults dropped significantly over 12 years, and about half of all Americans now have readings in the desirable range, experts said today. Results from a new national health survey showed a 4 percent decline in the average cholesterol level, to 205 milligrams per deciliter of blood in 1990 from 213 milligrams in 1978. A level below 200 milligrams is considered desirable. The survey also found that the proportion of adults with very high blood cholesterol levels fell to 20 percent from 26 percent.
